text:
In J.R.R. Tolkien's Lord of the Rings series, power is a pervasive and multifaceted theme that drives the plot and shapes the characters. The most obvious manifestation of power is the One Ring, of course, which grants its bearer unimaginable control over Middle-earth. However, of all the characters who come into contact with the Ring, only Sauron and Gollum are willing to succumb to its corrupting influence, to abandon their free will for the promise of dominance.

Tolkien suggests that true power does not come from external sources like magical artifacts, but rather from one's own character and convictions. This is exemplified in the figures of Aragorn, Gandalf, and Galadriel, each of whom possesses great authority without relying on the Ring or any other crutch. Their power stems from their wisdom, compassion, and unwavering commitment to justice, to the well-being of others.

Meanwhile, the dark lords Saruman and Sauron embody the dangers of unchecked power. Both begin as benevolent beings, Saruman a wizard, to guide the Free Peoples against darkness; Sauron a Valar, to aid the Children of Il√∫vatar but through pride and ambition, they gradually become consumed by their lust for domination.
